instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
Hi guys, I have this board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with 20V 0.01a , no water damage, no corrosion . Any help

Some measures

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 0.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>. 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB</SIGNAL> 0v

no short on PPBUS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
Very strange to get 20V without <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
BTW, test the board alone on the desk, without battery connected.
And post accurate information.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
Do not quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above?
Please, maintain forum aesthetic.

Are you really get 20V on USB-C meter with 0V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>???
Using original charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message: ok sorry, well whit 87w charger i got 20v and 0a but with 61w charger F3010 shows 5v 0v and 5V again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
87W charger is fake?

So 61W cycles 5-0-5V?
Both ports, in both directions have the same behaviour?
Be aware, charger can be connected in 4 ways, 2 for each port.

Check for short on all secondary supplies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message: Both ports and 4 ways same issue, when you say secondary supplies do you mean s3,s4,s0?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
Yes, start checking at big coils.
Don't forget to check behind power FETs.

Also post exact diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
diode mode

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.459
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.  0.377

no short on big coils again with another 61w charger got 20v 0.01a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont power on 20V on charger
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, when switch to 20V?
Any other coil gets voltage then?
